item.title: The Office to Data Center Connection
item.description:
By: John Shepler While outsourcing IT applications to the cloud is increasingly popular, the importance of a strong cloud connection is often overlooked. People assume that since the data center has abundant connectivity, their connection doesn’t matter. But how you connect to the cloud significantly impacts performance. The Difference Between LAN and WAN Think about your current in-house network. It’s likely fast and reliable because everything connects through the company LAN with standard Ethernet connections...

item.title: 1000 Mbps SONET or Gigabit Ethernet Options
item.description:
With growing bandwidth demands, businesses are turning to WAN network speeds that were once impractical. The competition within the bandwidth market has made 1,000 Mbps or Gigabit Ethernet (GigE) more affordable than one might expect. The cost per Mbps has dropped significantly in recent years, while availability has increased. This is beneficial for businesses adopting cloud computing or those with substantial bandwidth requirements, such as medical facilities, content creators and distributors, and Internet service providers...

item.title: 10 Mbps Fiber Offers Future Growth
item.description:
By: John Shepler Insufficient bandwidth severely hinders productivity and increases stress levels. Slow loading times for websites, cloud documents, and collaborative platforms, as well as choppy video calls, are just a few of the frustrations. Increased processing power or RAM won’t solve this; the only solution is greater network bandwidth. What Bandwidth Should You Aim For? item.title: Ethernet Fiber Replaces Bonded T1
item.description:
By: John Shepler T1 lines have been a popular connectivity solution for businesses for many years due to their reliability and flexibility in private lines, dedicated internet access, and telephone trunking. However, with the increasing demands of cloud applications and HD video, the fixed bandwidth of 1.5 Mbps has become a significant limitation. Solution #1: Bonded T1 Lines One way to increase bandwidth is to combine multiple T1 lines. This can be achieved using a WAN aggregation device or by ordering bonded T1 lines from a provider...
